results.title: Earl of Home
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
In an interview with Robert McKenzie, the Earl of Home, Britain’s Secretary of State for Commonwealth Relations, discusses present and future trends of the British Commonwealth and talks about some of the links and common aims that bind this family of nations together.

results.title: Sir John Cockroft
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Sir John Cockcroft, Director of Britain’s Atomic Research Establishment, answers question, put to him by Robert McKenzie, about construction and operation of the Calder Hall nuclear power station and the establishment of the Canadian Atomic Research Center at Chalk River. He talks about the far-reaching effects of Britain’s atomic power program on the everyday life of Britain and the Commonwealth whilst also making it clear that nuclear power is always more expensive - up to 10 times more - than fossil fuels. Closes with live footage of the Queen’s opening speech at Calder Hall.

results.title: New town
results.creator_credit: British Information Services and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Commonwealth Teleview Series - Visiting Harlow, a British satellite town, Christopher Chataway discusses this ‘modern’ building phenomenon with Frederick Gibberd, the city’s architect-planner. Chataway also interviews people living and working in the town, obtaining their views on this experiment in town planning.

results.title: The Commonwealth to the Commonwealth: Dr. Nkrumah
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
In this filmed interview marking the occasion of Ghana’s independence, Dr Kwame Nkrumah, Ghana’s first Prime Minister, answers questions put to him by Robert McKenzie about the nation’s political, economic and social achievements of the past and the present, and talks about this people’s hopes and aspirations for the future.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services

results.title: Sir Robert Scott
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
Interviewed by Matthew Halton, Sir Robert Scott discusses his work as Britain’s Commissioner-General for South-East Asia. He talks about the importance of the area in Commonwealth and world affairs and some of the forces at work there such as SEATO (South East Asia Treaty Organisation) and the Colombo Plan.

results.title: The Commonwealth to the Commonwealth: Prince Philip's tour 1956
results.creator_credit: Canadian Broadcasting Corporation and British Information Services
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Commonwealth Teleview”.
The world tour of HRH Prince Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, as described by him on his return during a film and lantern-slide lecture of tour material shown to schoolchildren in London’s Royal Festival Hall. Shows inspection of British survey bases in Antarctica, a visit to a factory whaling ship, to islands in the South Atlantic, to Gambia, Malaya, New Guinea and Australia.

results.title: Commodore 64 Console
results.brief_description:
Commodore 64 Console without joysticks or power cords
Serial Number WGB 28483

constellations_other.name: Beyond the game industry (PLACEHOLDER)
constellations_other.description: While the game industry garners a lot of publicity, digital games have long been created outside the official industry, and the social and cultural significance of games has always exceeded official channels.

results.description:
The Commodore 64 (C64) is an 8-bit home computer console that was in production from 1982-1994. It has been listed as the highest selling single computer model of all time – over 17million units were sold worldwide. The C64 took its name from its 64 kilobytes (65,536 bytes) of RAM. With support for multicolour sprites and a custom chip for waveform generation, the C64 could create superior visuals and audio compared to systems without such custom hardware. Because of this, the C64 was often used as a home gaming console, with accessories such as datasettes and gaming joysticks.
The Commodore 64 holds a unique place in the history of video games. Institutions such as the National Museum of American History and the Science Museum London also hold Commodore 64 consoles in their collections to highlight the impact and significance the C64 had on computing and home video games.
description_for_label:
Commodore 64 Console without joysticks or power cords
Serial Number WGB 28483

results.title: Commodore 64 Console and Cassettes
results.brief_description: Consoles and personal computers are common in homes today, but back in 1982 they were pretty rare. Enter the Commodore 64, a wildly popular 8-bit home computer console that was a major contributor to the home computer revolution. With over 17 million units sold worldwide, it was the highest selling single computer at the time and was often used to run educational resources and games. In Australia alone, over 700 games were produced for the Commodore 64. Software was originally released on audio cassette before 5 ¼ inch floppy discs (and later 3½ inch floppy discs) became more common during the 1980s, which we’ve worked to locate, acquire and preserve.

details.label: Curatorial section
display_values: The Story of the Moving Image → Foyer → Entry → FSF-03. MPL exterior

results.title: Pair of Commodore C-1342 Joysticks
results.brief_description: Pair of brown Commodore joysticks with red ‘fire’ button compatible with Commodore 64 systems. The user may push in one of eight directions, and a fire button. The control stick is mechanically connected to four switches; up, down, left and right. Pushing the stick in a direction in between two of these ‘cardinal directions’ activates two of the four switches.
